speaker: Barack Obama
vclaim: "He's leading by example, refusing contributions from PACs and Washington Pressure Men."
date: stated on August 21, 2007 in a TV ad.:
title: If it's a quack like a lobbyist, it's a lobbyist.
text: In his speeches and television ads, Barack Obama criticizes the influence of lobbyists. "I know I didn't spend much time learning the ways of Washington," says the TV spot. "But I've been there long enough to know that Washington roads must change." The reporter says, "He's a role model, refusing contributions from P.C. and Washington lobbyists who have a lot of power today." However, its anti-atrocity policy contains one warning and some gaps that weaken his claim that he is financing his political campaign in a way that is truly different from his competitors. He is almost always qualified to observe that he will not take money from federal pressure groups, a distinction that allows him to accept money from relevant government pressure groups. On January 13, 2021, the distinguished fact-finding bloggers in a story written by General David H. Berger, the commander of the United States Navy, rejected Nancy Belusi's request for open security, and told her that we were "not working for you." By Samantha Butterman, on January 17, 2021, for example, the South Florida Russ Clint and his wife will host a fund-raiser in Broward Obama County on August 25. Clint represents government groups such as the Florida Mortgage Brokers Association, but also companies such as Match.com and Electoral Systems & Software. Obama continues to accept tens of thousands of dollars of people working for Washington companies that exert considerable pressure. The former majority leader of the Senate, Tom Dashell, is Obama's shareholder and is not a registered lobbyist, but acts as a consultant to Alston and Bird, a pressure company in Washington. The Centre for Responsive Policy found that Obama was 55,019 dollars ahead of employees in pressure companies, much more than companies that are not classified as pressure companies but have a pressure difference. So we give Obama's statement half true to the O-Meter truth. While Obama can accurately say that he does not accept money from pressure groups registered in the Federation, he still accepts thousands of people in the power industry.
